name: Anonymous
com:
/vst/ is a place to discuss all types of strategy video games, including both turn-based and real-time strategy, turn-based and real-time tactics, single-player and multi-player (including MOBAs). All platforms are welcome.

Does this mean discussion of strategy games is banned on other video game boards? No! /vst/ is just a separate board specifically focused on strategy games where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vst/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/

name: Anonymous
com: If you were to create the UED as a fully-fledged faction in SC1 or 2, how would you design them, both aesthetically and in terms of gameplay?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1276860
Considering the Terrans are basically the backwater retards of humankinds, I feel the UED should be a much more advanced and "civilized" (at least on the surface) faction. Not like the Protoss but they should be a faction that tries to distance itself from the fighting. So they're not sending brainwashed grunts to get chewed up by zerg in trenches, instead they focus on automated drones and long-range weapons. They're a faction that has all the technology needed to wage war, but have lost touch with what a real war is like and see themselves above the actual fighting. So they've got strong air and long range options, but a limited "boots on the ground" factor and lacking in ways of dealing with short range and melee pressure.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1276872
Makes sense.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1276860
In terms of aesthetic, something similar to the Terrans but a little more sleek and streamlined, somewhere in between the Galactic Empire from Star Wars and the UNSC from Halo. Ship and vehicle designs are more angular than blocky, and their power armor has been refined down to the point where it’s only barley more bulky than a Nanosuit from Crysis. They would mainly use gauss guns for armor penetration and munitions projection and MASERs for fleshy targets. Some oversized and rudimentary plasma weaponry as well. Almost nothing is gunpowder-based.
Gameplay-wise, they would be based around using artillery and fast air units to soften up the opponent before mopping up with small squads of powerful but expensive infantry and vehicles. They struggle in massed, close-range scenarios with few options for close-up AoE, but can completely dismantle their foe from afar before moving in for the kill.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1277303
for assault: pikemen and crossbows. pikes trade about evenly against horses, but cost half as much. they are also good for attacking into buildings and okay into wooden fortifications. Crossbows are durable ranged units that have the nice property of being able to attack other units in the square they occupy.
for intercepting high value units: horsemen. Horses should only fight on open terrain. They're best used for sniping squishy ranged units like cannons and archers who are marching to a new location. Knights will do better against pikes, but knights are fucking expensive and you should probably not build them.
for defense: soldiers and archers. a full square of archers in a fortified position is deadly to any unit in the open and hard to defeat without siege weapons. Archers are very cheap to train. However, these units are shit in open terrain and will be torn apart by hast weapons.

Halbardiers are halfway between a soldier and a pike, and you should build them.
Coutilliers are rather garbage at everything, but they are cheap and can be used to fill squares and intrude, or to terrorize villagers.
Peasant soldiers are meme units that die to woodcutters.


The best unit in the game, however, is the city guard

I dropped it after an hour because it seemed like the combat would be extremly basic and repetitive (I suppose it's all just dealing with Action Points while using various weapons with only either range, damage or AP cost changing and maybe some simple mechanics like Healing, Lockpicking, basic AoE explosives, no? BG came out a year before this game)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1277517
it's an armed conflict so yes, primarily combat will be shooting guns
but there's a bit more than just that, if you can be bothered with it

if you have a strong and athletic sim, you can take chances on running up to enemies and knocking them out with hand-to-hand combat
if you knock out an enemy, you can steal the weapon he's holding (enemies don't always drop the weapon after dying but you can always try to steal it off them as long as they have it equipped)

when a fight in a sector starts but before the enemy actually spots you (not equivalent with turn-based mode being used), you will be in a stealthier "low awareness" mode. enemies will have a slightly less effective field of view, will generally walk or stand around rather than run, and are easier to get one-hit stealth kills on (especially with throwing knives)
some sectors are more rewarding to complete by doing them stealthily, for example in one of the sectors in Alma, you can get a special weapon if the alarm isn't raised

also, if you slip away from a sector without alerting or otherwise being spotted by the enemy, it doesn't count as a battle, so you won't lose team morale for doing so. you can use this for example to try slipping through town sectors without engaging enemies

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Previous thread:
>>1141027

https://pastebin.com/QgEvG3ET
>Higher resolution
Add DirectDraw=0 in the .ini file for SMAC or SMAX - it will make run the game at the desktop resolution; the only graphical drawback is that in the "customize random planet" menu the background won't be animated.
>Higher resolution & UI improvement
Install PRACX patch https://alphacentauri2.info/index.php?topic=14308.0 which is running for SMAC and SMAX. Adds:
- windowed mode,
- higher resolution,
- viewing tiles by hovering over them (V hotkey),
- potential yields view in the base view,
- alternative map view modes (elevation, rainfall, rockiness, faction territory),
- smoother zooming and scrolling.
Besides disabled "customize random planet" animation it also makes the mini-map view box unresponsive to the scrolling.
>In-game help update
https://forums.civfanatics.com/threads/comprehensive-datalinks-update.291246/ - corrects and expands the description of techs, abilities and so on. Available only for SMAX.
>CPU usage fix
Some people report high CPU usage, this fix works with SMAC/SMAX:
https://alphacentauri2.info/index.php?topic=20433.0
>SMAX vanilla conversion
https://alphacentauri2.info/index.php?topic=17869.0 - allows to play SMAC in the SMAX engine by removing all expansion assets.
>Unofficial patches
Several fan-made patches fixing bugs and improving AI:
https://alphacentauri2.info/wiki/Category:Unofficial_patches
>Custom factions
Not an exhaustive list. To enable a new faction in SMAX you need to open alphax.txt, find #CUSTOMFACTIONS line, and add the name used in the new faction .txt file like this:
#CUSTOMFACTIONS
FACTION, FACTION
No more than 7 custom factions can be added at the time.
In SMAC you can only replace existing factions (plus features introduced in SMAX won't work).
https://alphacentauri2.info/My%20Custom%20Factions/Custom%20Factions.htm
https://alphacentauri2.info/index.php?action=downloads;sa=view;down=102

com:
is a grand STRATEGY GAME that I have been developing, it's not "off-topic", even if it isn't complete.
Set in pseudo-Europe and inspired by Imperator, it seeks not to be another map painter but an empire manager, with a focus on:
>resource management (you need wood to build ships, grain to feed pops, wool to prevent them from freezing, etc)
>pop management (who all have their wealth)
>character management
>closed economy with prepaid-model
>anti-omniscience (limited information, e.g. you don't know many troops other countries have)
>faction management (all characters belong to a faction, and everything you do impact the faction's loyalty, if you go to war against the faction's beloved country, they might revolt against you)
>army management (army depletes as you advance because you have to leave troops behind to garrison)
>making the world evolve (you turn forests into farmlands, build bridges over rivers, convert villages to cities)

last_replies.com:
>>1277216
>other goes more science
There is no science faction, but factions relate culture, religion and government.
For example in the middle of the map, the Great Chiron Kingdom. It used to be a Luawun state that dominated the Continent prior to the arrival of the east Kuawun who deprived it of most of its possessions and force converted them their religion of Jivzism. Naturally, the unified Kuawun state of Droivacia itself collapsed a few centuries prior to the game start, allowing the Chiron to conquer parts of their kingdom gradually.

Hence, the factions of the Great Chiron Kingdom reflect its historical background. Their factions are:
>Chiron Supremacists, who wish to restore the ancient glory of the kingdom by reverting to the old religion, and recovering the old border, and because they consider themself superior, they don't wanna ally non-Chiron countries
>Kuawphiles, cucks who consider themself barbaric and wish to replace their own culture with a culture that belongs to the Kuawun group, they wish to ally with Kuawun countries
>Kuawuphobes, similar to the Chiron Supremacists, but they are obsessed with Kuawun hatred, they only want to fight the Kuawun
>Jivzi Adaptationalist , are devout followers of Jivzism who are moderates, they don't hate or love Kuawun, but they like their religion

So, if the Great Chiron Kingdom attacks a Kuawun country (all Kuawun countries follow Jivzism) it has the following impact:
>Chiron Supremacistsgain loyalty
>Kuawuphile lose loyalty
>Kuawuphobes gain loyalty
>Jivzi Adaptationalists lose loyalty

If the Kingdom attacks the southern Uhzan Kingdom (who are ruled by Soffirish but follow Jivzism):
>Chiron Supremacists gain loyalty
>Kuawuphiles gain loyalty
>Kuawuphobes lose loyalty
>Jivzi Adaptationalists lose loyalty

If the Kingdom attack the northern Duegeuns (who follow their own pagan religion):
>Chiron Supremacists gain loyalty
>Kuawuphiles gain loyalty
>Kuawuphobes lose loyalty
>Jivzi Adaptationalists gain loyalty

>>1275524
>Will going from using a mouse and some keys to using only hotkeys increase my chances of winning in ao2 de?
It will allow you to execute actions much faster. If you are in all other ways equal to your opponent (in game knowledge, build order knowledge, multitasking/macro, micro, "game sense" etc) then being faster than them is a pretty significant advantage. It doesn't guarantee a win over them, because it's still up to you to make the most of your advantage. If you're faster to feudal / castle and are ahead in eco because of your superior speed, but don't use this to beat your opponent, then it doesn't matter how fast you are.

com:
Why are hexfags so fucking retarded they cannot see the forest for the trees?

See picrel for why why the "diagonal movement problem" hexfags try to ascribe to squares doesn't actually exist - because you are moving in tiles, not actual distance! It doesn't matter that you have moved 1.41 feet diagonally, when you would have moved only 1 foot orthgonaly, becasue YOU ARE NOT MOVING IN REAL DISTANCE, YOU ARE MOVING IN TILES.
See picrel, it takes the exact same amount of tiles to move from one corner to the next diagonally, that it takes to move from one corner to the next orthogonally.
Yes the real distance is larger, but that does not matter, since the game is structured in tiles, not real distance!

Hexxfagging is unirinically Reddit-style thinking - believing you are some sort of expert and can overturn years of time-tested methods because you have learned some arbitrary fun fact (in this case that distance from one center of a square to the center of diagonal square is larger than the distance to the center of a orthogonal square).

TL;DR: 1 tile = 1 tile, always

>>1268054
>What's the appeal of this game?
build autismo, mainly, since there is an absurd amount of interactions between the masteries and such.
but it also has very interesting things that make its tactical layer better than NuCom's
>dynamic turn system instead of 'i go, you go'
>terrain matters beyond mere height difference
>even time of the day and climate matter
>chain effects (ie: pushing an enemy into an obstacle or someone else stuns them, a flashbang in the dark causes confusion instead of blind, receiving a lightning crit while on water stuns you, etc)

> I don't get it, does it get any better later on?
it does, and it is arguably the weak point of the game, that it takes too long to actually be able to exploit all the mechanics the game has since the early game is extremely limited in how many mastery slots and characters you have (also since your characters have low speed and there aren't many ways to reduce your AT, it is also very slow and you'll have to wait a lot between turns)

com:
Diplomacy update in 5 days lads

>A full-featured diplomacy system. The AI takes a "realpolitik" approach, and the system explains in detail why the AI likes or dislikes a diplomatic action. So no AI opponents that hate or love you for no clear reason. Your diplomatic actions also affect your reputation in the world as a whole.

>I'm especially pleased with the ultimatum system, where you can send an interaction saying "do this or else I'll do this other thing". This can be "pay me tribute or I declare war" but also more out there things like "upgrade our non-aggression pact pact to a defensive pact or I'll cancel our trade treaty".

>You can now upgrade your towns and cities with shipyards, factories, police stations, pleasure palaces, labs, and more. Balance your expenditures between building up your empire and conquering more of it.

>There are new systems for logistics and city unrest, as well as a fully rewritten espionage system, a revamped technology tree, and a much prettier new map.

>Finally, there are now special eras in conquest that change things up by having special rules. Like an Age of Piety that reduces unrest and gives the players a bunch of holy sites to fight over. Or an Age of Exploration that lets the players send out expeditions to find knowledge and valuables.
